title: Leave voters not prepared to lose money in return for immigration controls, survey shows
text:
News Leave voters not prepared to lose money in return for immigration controls, survey shows A new survey found 54% of Leave voters would not be prepared for their family finances to be affected by the government prioritising immigration over the economy Share The Prime Minister is reportedly set to head for a 'full on' hard Brexit (Photo: Dan Kitwood) Share Get politics   Thank you for subscribing! Could   
More than half of Leave voters are not prepared to be a penny worse off in order for Britain to regain control of immigration, a new poll has found. 
It comes as Theresa May is reportedly set to yank the UK out of the Single Market as part of a ‘full on’ hard Brexit . 
The YouGov survey, commissioned by Open Britain, found 54% of Leave voters would not be prepared for their family finances to be affected by the government prioritising immigration over the economy. 
Just 11% of people who backed Brexit said they would be prepared to be more than £100 a month worse off in return for greater controls on immigration. Theresa May (Photo: Rex Features) 
Tory MP Nicky Morgan said the poll underlined the public's desre for the Government to avoid a "blinkered focus" on immigration. 
She said: "The Government will be doing a disservice to the country and to both Leave and Remain voters if it dogmatically pursues a hard, destructive Brexit where immigration control is the be-all-and-end-all, our economy is undermined, and people are left poorer. “Many Leave campaigners were clear that the referendum was not about immigration but about issues such as sovereignty. Now is the time for them to step up and stand behind their statements. 
“Leave voters were told they could have immigration control and economic prosperity, and the onus is on the Government to deliver that for them. That means aiming high in the negotiations, not conceding anything at the start, and putting maximum participation in the Single Market at the heart of their strategy, not treating economic policy as an afterthought.” Like us on Facebook
